children: Symptom concerns are responsible for nearly half of all outpatient visits. Although most symptoms resolve within several weeks, clinicians are challenged to determine symptom significance and the role of testing in the diagnostic approach. Unnecessary testing accounts for nearly 30% of health care costs, and physicians have a responsibility when evaluating symptoms to use testing strategies that offer the highest value. Fortunately, a thorough history alone generates the highest diagnostic yield—up to 75% in some studies—with physical examination contributing an additional 10% to 15%. In contrast, testing results in less than 10% of diagnoses. Diagnostic testing may provide information that justifies the costs; however, physicians should consider the value of testing and the effects of test results on patient management.

This chapter focuses on high-value approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of commonly encountered symptoms, including cough, dizziness, dyspnea, fatigue, insomnia, lower extremity edema and ulcers, medically unexplained symptoms, and syncope. In-flight emergencies, a common event encountered by physicians, also are reviewed.

Cough results in roughly 30 million physician office visits annually in the United States, costing billions of dollars. An evidence-based and cost-effective approach to the evaluation of cough is based on cough duration (acute, subacute, or chronic).

Acute cough (<3 weeks' duration) most often is caused by viral infections, including upper respiratory tract infections and bronchitis. Other conditions that may present with acute cough include allergic rhinosinusitis, pneumonia, medication adverse effects, and pulmonary edema.

The initial evaluation of the patient with acute cough focuses on identifying potentially life-threatening illnesses. Concomitant fever, dyspnea, chest pain, and abnormalities on lung or cardiovascular examination suggest a serious respiratory or cardiovascular disease as the source of cough, and further evaluation should be completed as appropriate. Chest radiography is indicated with suspicion of pneumonia; findings that support obtaining a chest radiograph include abnormal vital signs (heart rate >100/min, respiration rate >24/min, temperature >38.0 °C [100.4 °F]), abnormal lung examination findings (rales, egophony, or tactile fremitus), and altered mental status.

Acute cough without evidence of lower respiratory tract infection or cardiovascular disease is most often caused by acute bronchitis or viral rhinosinusitis. Coronaviruses and rhinoviruses are the most common causative pathogens; influenza virus should be highly suspected in patients presenting with sudden-onset fever and myalgia, especially during influenza season (between autumn and early spring). For additional information on SARS-CoV-2, see COVID-19: An ACP Physician's Guide (

). Bacterial infections also can cause acute sinusitis or bronchitis, although sinus imaging is not recommended unless a complication, such as spread of infection into contiguous structures, is suspected.

Another important cause of acute cough is therapy with an ACE inhibitor. Up to 20% of patients taking an ACE inhibitor develop a dry cough, usually within 1 to 2 weeks of therapy initiation, although cough onset may be delayed by months in a small percentage of patients. Cough usually subsides within days of discontinuation of the offending agent but can persist for weeks in some cases. All ACE inhibitors can cause this side effect. Angiotensin receptor blockers typically do not cause cough and may be substituted if ACE inhibitor therapy is not tolerated.

Treatment of acute cough is primarily symptomatic and dependent on the underlying etiology. The mainstay of treatment of bronchitis is patient education and reassurance that the cough usually resolves in 2 to 3 weeks. Empiric treatment of acute bronchitis or upper respiratory tract infection with antibiotics is ineffective; increases bacterial antibiotic resistance; and may cause multiple adverse effects, including

colitis. Antibiotics should not be initiated without clearly established bacterial infection, and most patients with acute bacterial sinusitis will improve without antibiotics. A limited number of studies suggest that honey may decrease cough frequency and severity. Patients suspected of having acute bronchitis should be counseled to return if symptoms do not improve; further evaluation and antibiotic therapy should be considered in patients with worsening or persistent symptoms. Treatment of acute rhinosinusitis includes intranasal glucocorticoids. Limited evidence supports the effectiveness of other treatments, including saline irrigation, antihistamines, and decongestants (see
Subacute cough (3-8 weeks' duration) is most often postinfectious after acute respiratory tract infection, particularly viral or

infection. It is usually caused by postnasal drip or airway hyperreactivity. First-generation antihistamines may be beneficial in patients with postnasal drip. Asthma therapies are usually effective in patients with evidence of airway hyperreactivity, such as wheezing. Patients with postinfectious cough not attributed to postnasal drip or airway hyperreactivity may benefit from inhaled ipratropium.

infection should be considered in patients with subacute cough characterized by paroxysms of severe coughing and posttussive emesis. If infectious causes of subacute cough are excluded, the evaluation shifts to consideration of the causes of chronic cough.

Chronic cough (>8 weeks' duration) is most often caused by upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) (formerly known as postnasal drip syndrome), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), asthma, smoking, and ACE inhibitor use. Nonasthmatic eosinophilic bronchitis (NAEB) is another increasingly recognized etiology. Important but less common causes include chronic bronchitis, lung neoplasm, bronchiectasis, and chronic aspiration.
Evaluation of chronic cough begins with a thorough history, physical examination, and chest radiography

. Therapy for specific causes should be initiated on the basis of the initial evaluation. ACE inhibitor therapy and tobacco use should be discontinued. If the cause is not determined after initial evaluation, a stepwise approach is pursued, beginning with a 2-week trial of empiric treatment for UACS. Allergic rhinitis–associated UACS is optimally treated with intranasal glucocorticoids, whereas UACS resulting from nonallergic rhinitis responds best to first-generation antihistamines (chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine, diphenhydramine) and decongestants (pseudoephedrine) (see

Asthma should be considered in patients with symptoms that do not respond to empiric treatment for UACS. Cough-variant asthma is diagnosed if spirometry and/or bronchial hyperresponsiveness testing results are abnormal and symptoms improve with standard therapy for asthma, including inhaled glucocorticoids.

In patients with normal findings on evaluation and in whom empiric treatment for UACS and asthma has failed, the most reasonable next step is to exclude NAEB with sputum analysis for eosinophils or exhaled nitric oxide testing. If test results are abnormal, therapy with inhaled glucocorticoids should be initiated.

Cough without a clear etiology that does not appear secondary to UACS, asthma, or NAEB may be treated with antireflux lifestyle changes to address possible GERD; empiric proton pump inhibitor therapy also may be considered.
Patients with partial responses to treatment for UACS, asthma, NAEB, and/or GERD should continue those therapies. More advanced investigation may be necessary in some patients (see

Persistent cough without an identifiable cause despite comprehensive evaluation is termed unexplained chronic cough. Patients with unexplained chronic cough may benefit from other therapies for symptomatic relief. Multimodality speech pathology therapy may provide benefit and should be offered to all patients with chronic cough of undetermined cause. Antitussives, including dextromethorphan and topical anesthetics (benzonatate), have been shown to reduce cough and improve quality of life. Gabapentin may be effective for unexplained chronic cough and should be considered if the risk for adverse effects is acceptable. Protussives, such as guaifenesin, can improve mucus clearance and cough intensity in selected patients with excessive sputum production. Opioids, such as codeine, may be effective but should be used with caution and only if other measures fail.

The evaluation of cough in ambulatory immunocompromised patients should follow the same protocol as for immunocompetent patients; however, immunocompromised patients require heightened suspicion for infections, particularly if immunosuppression is severe and common causes of cough have been excluded. Aside from common pathogens, other causes to consider include fungi, cytomegalovirus, varicella, herpesvirus, and

. Regardless of radiographic findings, tuberculosis should be considered in the initial evaluation of patients with HIV infection and subacute or chronic cough who reside in regions with a high prevalence of tuberculosis. Clinicians should have a low threshold for initiating empiric antibiotic therapy while diagnostic testing is pursued.

Hemoptysis is expectoration of blood from the lower respiratory tract. Acute bronchitis is a common cause of mild and self-limited hemoptysis; more serious causes include bronchiectasis, cancer, tuberculosis, pulmonary embolism, and left ventricular failure. Rare causes include anti–glomerular basement membrane antibody disease (Goodpasture syndrome) and granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Hemoptysis requires urgent evaluation, beginning with assessment to confirm the lower respiratory tract as the source of bleeding and exclude epistaxis or hematemesis. Chest radiography should be performed, but many patients additionally require chest CT and/or bronchoscopy to determine the cause.

Chest radiography is not indicated in the evaluation of acute cough in the absence of abnormal vital signs or lung examination findings, unless there are other concerning clinical features (e.g., altered mental status).
Treatment of acute cough is primarily symptomatic; antibiotics are not recommended in patients with acute bronchitis or upper respiratory tract infection without a clear bacterial cause.
Common causes of chronic cough include smoking, ACE inhibitor use, upper airway cough syndrome, gastroesophageal reflux disease, asthma, and nonasthmatic eosinophilic bronchitis.
Patients with unexplained chronic cough may benefit from multimodality speech pathology therapy, antitussives, and/or gabapentin.

title.__html: Approach to the Patient With Dizziness

children: Approach to the Patient With Dizziness

Dizziness is a common, nonspecific symptom seen in inpatient and outpatient settings. Patients often interchangeably use such terms as “dizzy,” “lightheaded,” “woozy,” “cloudy,” “faint,” or “off-balance” to describe the perception of dizziness. Owing to its subjective nature, variability in symptom description, and broad differential diagnosis (which includes posterior circulation stroke and other life-threatening disorders), dizziness is a challenging symptom to assess and treat.

A relevant history and physical examination should be performed to classify dizziness into one of four focused groupings: vertigo, presyncope, disequilibrium, and nonspecific dizziness. This classification facilitates establishing a formal diagnosis and treatment strategy.

Vertigo is patient perception of false personal or environmental movement. Patients describe a spinning or whirling sensation, which is often accompanied by concomitant nausea, vomiting, and sudden-onset fatigue. Symptoms are typically episodic and brief and are often triggered by positional changes of the head. Vertigo is classified as peripheral or central, depending on the specific etiology.

A thorough history and examination are crucial for differentiating between central and peripheral causes, especially in patients with acute vertigo concerning for vertebrobasilar ischemia and other central etiologies. Major causes of acute vertigo are presented in
. Examination should include an in-depth neurologic assessment and, in the case of acute persistent vertigo, the HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew) oculomotor assessment
. Demonstration of the HINTS assessment in a normal patient can be viewed at

Common causes of peripheral vertigo include benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV), vestibular neuronitis, labyrinthitis, Meniere disease, medication effects (toxicity from aminoglycoside or diuretic use), Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster involving cranial nerve VII), and vestibular schwannoma (acoustic neuroma).

BPPV is the most common form of vertigo, with a lifetime prevalence of 2.4%. It is more common in women (female-to-male ratio of 2:1 to 3:1). BPPV is caused by displacement and migration of otoconia (calcium carbonate crystals) within the semicircular canals. Up to 90% of cases of BPPV involve the posterior semicircular canal because it is the most gravity-dependent semicircular canal.

BPPV is characterized by sudden-onset, recurrent, and brief (usually <1 minute) vertiginous symptoms that are provoked and worsened with positional changes of the head. Patients report dizziness, imbalance, nausea, and vomiting; however, no focal neurologic findings are present. Symptoms lead to increased risk for falls and a decline in functional status. Positive answers to the following three questions have been found to be helpful in the diagnosis of BPPV: (1) Do you have spinning or a whirling sensation of the surroundings or yourself? (2) Do you feel dizzy mostly when your head is moved? (3) Does the dizziness last less than 3 minutes? The sensitivity, specificity, and precision of these questions is 87.0%, 89.8%, and 80.0%, respectively. These questions may be helpful for in-office visits as well in the telephone triage of patients with acute-onset dizziness.
The diagnostic test of choice for BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver
, which also can help differentiate between peripheral and central causes of vertigo

. In the setting of BPPV, a positive finding includes the presence of a mixed upbeat-torsional nystagmus toward the affected side. Brain imaging is unnecessary for diagnosis of BPPV. First-line therapy is canalith repositioning with the Epley maneuver, which is effective in up to 85% of patients

Vestibular neuronitis is most often preceded by a viral infection affecting the vestibular portion of cranial nerve VIII. Symptoms are generally more severe and of longer duration than in BPPV and may take longer to resolve. Labyrinthitis has a presentation similar to that of vestibular neuronitis with the additional symptom of hearing loss. Meniere disease presents with vertigo lasting less than 24 hours accompanied by tinnitus, hearing loss, or fullness in the affected ear; symptoms are episodic and recurrent and may be severe.

Diuretics and the vasodilator betahistine (not available in the United States) may reduce symptoms of Meniere disease, but pharmacologic therapy has not otherwise been shown to be significantly effective for peripheral vertigo. Rather, vestibular suppressants (antihistamines, benzodiazepines, and antiemetics) can be used in conjunction with other forms of therapy for temporary symptomatic relief. If vestibular suppressants are selected, treatment duration must be limited because these agents impede vestibular functioning, vestibular recovery, and the central compensatory mechanism.

Vestibular and balance rehabilitation therapy (VBRT) is effective in the treatment of various forms of dizziness (vertigo, disequilibrium, and nonspecific dizziness), although the Epley maneuver is the treatment of choice for BPPV. VBRT focuses on balance training, core stabilization, and desensitization exercises. Therapy is often performed by physical and occupational therapists. Internet-based therapy may be an attractive option for patients (

). Clinical trials have demonstrated that both standalone internet-based vestibular rehabilitation and combined internet-based rehabilitation and face-to-face physiotherapy support are clinically effective and safe interventions to treat adults with a chronic vestibular syndrome.

Central vertigo is a frequently missed and potentially life-threatening diagnosis. It may be caused by vertebrobasilar stroke (posterior circulation ischemic or hemorrhagic events), migraine, central nervous system infection, trauma (concussion, traumatic brain injury), demyelinating disease (multiple sclerosis), or chronic alcoholism. Risk factors for posterior circulation stroke include advanced age, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus, peripheral vascular disease, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia.

Patients with central vertigo secondary to vertebrobasilar stroke frequently display neurologic findings, such as nystagmus, dysphagia, dysarthria, diplopia, ataxia, postural instability, hemiparesis, and mental status changes. On HINTS assessment, the presence of a normal head impulse test, direction-changing nystagmus, or skew deviation additionally suggest a central cause. Approximately 20% of patients with vertebrobasilar stroke present with isolated vertigo, and studies have shown that up to one third of these cases are misclassified as peripheral vertigo. To a lesser extent, neurologic findings may be present in patients with other central processes, but they are not present in peripherally mediated forms of vertigo.

Imaging should be performed in patients with central vertigo. MRI is more sensitive than CT in detecting ischemic stroke and can detect infarction in the posterior fossa, often within minutes of symptom onset. CT provides an effective and expedited evaluation of hemorrhagic stroke, although hemorrhagic vertebrobasilar stroke accounts for a very small percentage of cases of centrally mediated vertigo.

Presyncope is a temporary reduction in global cerebral perfusion, causing symptoms of lightheadedness, dizziness, visual changes (tunnel vision), auditory changes, a sense of impending doom, warmth, nausea, and near loss of consciousness. Patients often report the sensation of “almost blacking out.” Postural tone is retained. In contrast, syncope is transient reduction in global cerebral perfusion, leading to a true loss of consciousness and loss of postural tone. Notably, patients with presyncope do not have vertigo. The differential diagnosis for presyncope is similar to that for syncope (see

Disequilibrium refers to a sensation of imbalance or unsteadiness that is primarily experienced during positional changes, standing, or walking and is relieved with sitting or lying down. Disequilibrium predominantly affects older adults, and its prevalence increases with age. Falls are four times more likely in patients with disequilibrium and are in turn associated with significant morbidity, functional decline, and fear of future falls.

The etiology of disequilibrium is thought to be multifactorial and can involve visual and auditory impairment; muscle weakness or atrophy; physical deconditioning; pain; and/or impairment in proprioception, balance, and gait. Disequilibrium must be differentiated from specific causes of gait abnormalities and ataxia, such as movement disorders (Parkinson disease) (see

). Brain MRI in patients with disequilibrium has shown significantly more subcortical white-matter lesions and frontal atrophy than in patients without disequilibrium, although the significance of these findings is unclear.

Given the multifactorial nature of disequilibrium, treatment should be multifaceted. Treatment options include visual and auditory corrective measures (eyeglasses, hearing aids), medication review (to mitigate side effects), mobility aids, physical therapy (balance and gait training), weight-bearing and resistance exercises, and fall prevention counseling.

Dizziness that remains nonspecific despite a thorough history, examination, and evaluation is referred to as persistent postural-perceptual dizziness (PPPD) (formerly known as chronic subjective dizziness). PPPD is described as persistent, nonvertiginous dizziness or imbalance that worsens with personal motion, upright positioning, and movement of objects in the surrounding environment. Symptoms must be present on most days for at least 3 months. PPPD is often preceded by another vestibular process (BPPV, vestibular neuronitis, vestibular migraine, or stroke), trauma (concussion or traumatic brain injury), infection, or certain psychiatric conditions (anxiety, panic disorder, or major depression). Approximately 75% of patients with PPPD have concomitant anxiety or depressive symptoms. Diagnosis is typically made on the basis of chronic symptoms without an alternative cause after an appropriate evaluation.
Treatment options for PPPD include pharmacologic therapies (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors and serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors) and ongoing VBRT.
The diagnostic test of choice for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver; routine imaging is not recommended.
First-line therapy for benign paroxysmal positional vertigo is canalith repositioning with the Epley maneuver.
Patients with central vertigo often display focal neurologic findings, but approximately 20% of patients with vertebrobasilar stroke present with isolated vertigo.

Evaluation of patients with vertigo includes an in-depth neurologic assessment and, in the case of acute persistent vertigo, the HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew) oculomotor assessment.

Treatment options for disequilibrium include visual and auditory corrective measures, medication changes, mobility aids, physical therapy, weight-bearing and resistance exercises, and fall prevention counseling.

Dyspnea is a common symptom with a diverse pathophysiologic basis and substantial variation in patient experience. The prevalence of dyspnea increases with age; more than one third of persons older than 65 years report dyspnea in an ambulatory setting. Dyspnea affects up to half of hospitalized patients and is a common reason for patients to seek care in urgent and emergent care settings.

Dyspnea is caused by multiple underlying neurophysiologic mechanisms, including greater work of breathing, air hunger, and airway irritation or damage. These mechanisms may be triggered by poor functional status, organ-specific pathology, medication effects, or physiologic stimuli (including hypoxia and hypercapnia).

The history and physical examination are the most important components of the evaluation of dyspnea. An essential aspect of the history is the patient's qualitative description of dyspnea, which may aid in the diagnosis. Chest tightness may be relatively specific for bronchoconstriction, whereas smothering or suffocating at rest may suggest heart failure. Air hunger and “inability to get a deep breath” are commonly associated with hyperinflation (such as that caused by COPD) or restrictive conditions (such as pulmonary fibrosis).
The onset, duration, and progression of dyspnea may suggest an etiology

. Although exercise-induced dyspnea occurs with most causes of dyspnea, its absence may suggest a functional cause. Seasonal or diurnal dyspnea may occur with asthma, and worsening during the winter months is often associated with COPD.

Worsening of dyspnea with positional changes can provide useful clues. Orthopnea suggests heart failure, whereas breathlessness relieved by lying down (platypnea-orthodeoxia) suggests hepatopulmonary syndrome or a large patent foramen ovale. Dyspnea when lying on one side (trepopnea) has been associated with decompensated heart failure, diaphragmatic paralysis, and severe tricuspid regurgitation. Nocturnal dyspnea may suggest asthma, heart failure, or GERD. The onset of dyspnea when leaning forward (bendopnea), such as when tying shoelaces, is a newly described symptom of heart failure.

A thorough evaluation for associated symptoms may further narrow the differential diagnosis. For example, a productive cough may characterize COPD and pneumonia, and a dry cough can be associated with interstitial lung diseases and cough-variant asthma. A nocturnal cough may suggest GERD or asthma. Chest tightness or pressure may signal acute coronary syndrome or pulmonary embolism. Unilateral or pleuritic chest pain suggests pulmonary embolism, pneumonia, or other pleural-based conditions (e.g., pneumothorax).

In the absence of an obvious etiology, the initial evaluation may include measurement of oxygen saturation and hemoglobin, ECG, and chest radiography. In the correct clinical scenario, B-type natriuretic peptide or

-terminal pro–B-type natriuretic peptide levels are useful for ruling out heart failure. In patients with predicted low or intermediate risk for pulmonary embolism, an age-adjusted D-dimer cutoff is useful for ruling out this condition. Echocardiography is indicated for the evaluation of dyspnea of suspected cardiac origin. Point-of-care lung ultrasonography is an accurate means of rapidly detecting pleural effusion, interstitial syndrome (e.g., pulmonary edema, acute respiratory distress syndrome), alveolar consolidation, and pneumothorax. Advanced imaging of the cardiac or pulmonary systems should be pursued only when the initial evaluation reveals a reasonable likelihood of disease. Cardiopulmonary exercise testing can be helpful if the initial evaluation is unrevealing, deconditioning is a possibility, or multiple problems may be contributing to dyspnea. Referral to a cardiologist or pulmonologist may be appropriate when the diagnosis remains elusive or when conditions require subspecialized input.

Initial management strategies are aimed at treating or modifying the patient's dyspnea generator and underlying disease state. In patients with chronic conditions, the first step in reducing dyspnea is to maximize standard therapies, with regular assessment of symptom response.

In patients with persistent debilitating symptoms despite maximal medical therapy, there are nonpharmacologic and pharmacologic strategies to reduce dyspnea severity, each with varying levels of evidence. Of these therapies, pursed lip breathing, diaphragmatic breathing, handheld fans, and devices that enhance airflow are the least invasive and easiest to administer. Pulmonary rehabilitation provides significant benefit for patients with chronic lung disease and improves dyspnea in patients with COPD; exercise is the component primarily responsible for symptom relief.
Oxygen therapy improves survival and quality of life in patients with hypoxemia and COPD. However, the role of supplemental oxygen in patients without hypoxemia is less clear.

Opioids are an effective therapy for patients with dyspnea refractory to nonpharmacologic therapies and maximal medical management of the underlying disease. Opioids appear to exert an antidyspneic effect through modulation of sensory input in the central nervous system, similar to how they modulate pain signaling. Although opioids affect respiratory mechanics and may blunt respiratory drive, appropriately dosed opioids do not cause respiratory depression if treatment is symptom directed. Patient selection and subsequent opioid selection should be based on symptom burden, underlying disease, comorbid organ dysfunction, and overall risk for respiratory depression. Although systemic opioids have shown clear benefit in treating refractory dyspnea, inhaled opioids have not shown efficacy in several placebo-controlled trials. Other therapies found to be ineffective or lacking in sufficient data to recommend their use include anxiolytics, antidepressants, phenothiazines, indomethacin, nitrous oxide, and sodium bicarbonate.
Management of dyspnea in patients with serious illness is discussed in

In patients with dyspnea, point-of-care lung ultrasonography is an accurate means of rapidly detecting pleural effusion, interstitial syndromes (e.g., pulmonary edema, acute respiratory distress syndrome), alveolar consolidation, and pneumothorax, and it is safer and less expensive than radiography and CT.

Cardiopulmonary exercise testing can be helpful in the evaluation of dyspnea if the initial evaluation is unrevealing, deconditioning is a possibility, or multiple problems may be contributing to dyspnea.

title.__html: Fatigue and Systemic Exertion Intolerance Disease

children: Fatigue and Systemic Exertion Intolerance Disease

Fatigue is a truly subjective symptom, with little to no corroborating objective measures. It can be described as tiredness, exhaustion, reduction in endurance, or lack of physical or mental energy. Fatigue may be categorized as acute (<1 month's duration), subacute (1-6 months' duration), or chronic (>6 months' duration).

Fatigue occurs in one quarter to one third of patients in the primary care setting. Despite its high prevalence, the cause is often elusive, leading to prolonged delays in diagnosis, substantial functional decline, and high direct and indirect societal costs.
Fatigue is most often secondary to a specific underlying cause

or multiple factors (termed chronic multifactorial fatigue). It can occur as a primary condition, such as in systemic exertion intolerance disease, although this is a diagnosis of exclusion. The diagnostic evaluation of fatigue begins with a careful history and physical examination. Clinicians should note the duration, preceding factors, concomitant symptoms, prolonged deleterious lifestyle factors, medication use, and the presence of “red flag” signs or symptoms that suggest a serious underlying etiology (fever, involuntary weight loss, persistent lymphadenopathy, muscle atrophy, and synovitis). Patients should be assessed for an underlying sleep disorder as well.

Diagnostic testing choices should be driven by the history and physical examination findings. In patients with fatigue without a clear cause, it is reasonable to obtain a complete blood count, electrolyte panel, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, fasting glucose level, and kidney and liver chemistry tests. Laboratory, imaging, and invasive studies without a clear indication should be avoided because most patients will have unrevealing or contradictory findings that provide little reassurance to the patient or clinician.

Some patients experience progressive, debilitating fatigue with no identifiable cause despite an appropriate evaluation. In the past, this condition was termed chronic fatigue syndrome, myalgic encephalitis, or neurasthenia. Each of these diagnoses had different criteria, creating inconsistencies in diagnosis and treatment. In 2015, the Institute of Medicine issued an extensive guideline establishing evidence-based, consensus-based clinical diagnostic criteria under the consolidated term of systemic exertion intolerance disease (SEID). Diagnosis of SEID requires the presence of all of the following three symptoms:

A substantial reduction or impairment in the ability to engage in pre-illness levels of occupational, educational, social, or personal activities that persists for more than 6 months and is accompanied by fatigue, which is often profound, is of new or definite onset (not lifelong), is not the result of ongoing excessive exertion, and is not substantially alleviated by rest
In addition, the patient must have at least one of the following two manifestations:
Orthostatic intolerance (symptoms such as lightheadedness, dizziness, and headache that worsen with upright posture and improve with recumbency)

Although the pathophysiology of SEID remains unclear, central sensitization may contribute. Studies have demonstrated alterations in the function of immune cells, particularly natural killer cells, in patients with SEID; however, these changes are thought to be a biomarker of the disease rather than the cause. There is no convincing evidence that indolent chronic infection plays a role.

Comorbid conditions, such as fibromyalgia, irritable bowel syndrome, and interstitial cystitis, are common. Mood disorders often occur concomitantly in patients with SEID (approximately 70% of patients), and all patients with SEID should be screened for depression and anxiety. In addition, clinicians should ensure that all age-appropriate screening has been performed. Sleep disorders can coexist with SEID and do not invalidate a diagnosis of SEID if identified.

Treatment of fatigue should focus on correcting any underlying causes. In patients with SEID, treatment is supportive and focuses on treatment of symptoms and comorbid conditions. Patients benefit most from a structured multimodal approach that includes regularly scheduled office visits, patient education, and longitudinal reassessment. Pacing strategies, in which specific limits are placed on the degree of exertion, may help patients avoid “push-and-crash” cycles (overexertion resulting in worsening of symptoms, known as postexertional malaise). All patients should also receive instruction on effective sleep hygiene. Other modalities that may be of benefit include physical therapy, occupational therapy, biofeedback therapy, massage therapy, acupuncture, yoga, tai chi, and stress management activities. In patients with mood disorders, referral to a psychiatrist or psychologist is reasonable.

There are no FDA-approved medications for the treatment of SEID, and no medications have shown consistent, reproducible benefit. Medical therapy is therefore typically limited to the treatment of symptoms and comorbid conditions. Despite evidence of cytokine activation and altered immune system function, randomized trials targeting these pathways with immunomodulators, such as anakinra or rituximab, have failed to demonstrate benefit in patients with SEID. There is no consistent evidence that stimulants (including amphetamines), opioids, glucocorticoids, pharmacologic sleep aids, prolonged antibiotics or antiviral agents, or immunotherapies improve symptoms or disease course.

The prognosis for SEID varies and is often a source of frustration for patients and physicians alike. It depends on many factors, including patient age, formal education level, severity and duration of symptoms, decline in functional status relative to premorbid level of functioning, presence of other symptoms, comorbid conditions, and availability of resources.

In patients with fatigue without a clear cause, it is reasonable to obtain a complete blood count, electrolyte panel, thyroid-stimulating hormone level, fasting glucose level, and kidney and liver chemistry tests.
Patients with systemic exertion intolerance disease benefit most from a structured, multimodal approach that includes regularly scheduled office visits.
There are no FDA-approved medications for the treatment of systemic exertion intolerance disease, and medical therapy is limited to the management of comorbid conditions.

Insomnia is a complex health problem manifesting as poor sleep quality, frustration with sleep quantity, difficulty initiating sleep, or inability to return to sleep after awakening. The prevalence of insomnia increases with age, and women tend to be affected more than are men. Medical disorders, including cardiopulmonary diseases, neurodegenerative disorders, and psychiatric disorders, are often implicated in sleep disruption. Medications and other substances, such as caffeine, alcohol, glucocorticoids, diuretics, and antidepressants, also commonly contribute to symptoms of insomnia.

Chronic insomnia is diagnosed by the presence of symptoms that (1) cause substantial functional distress or impairment; (2) occur at least 3 nights per week for at least 3 months; and (3) are not associated with other sleep, medical, or mental disorders. Although 1 in 10 adults meet the diagnostic criteria for chronic insomnia, some studies have shown that up to 50% of adults report experiencing sleep problems.

All patients should be asked about problems of sleep disruption, given the wide range of affected patients and the substantial impact insufficient sleep can have on function. In patients with symptoms of insomnia, a thorough history and physical examination may point to potentially reversible causes, such as sleep apnea or restless legs syndrome. Eliciting an accurate medication history, including use of over-the-counter medications, herbal supplements, caffeine, alcohol, tobacco, and illicit drugs, is also an important part of the diagnostic approach. Physicians should obtain information on sleep pattern, including sleep difficulties (sleep initiation, sleep maintenance, sleep quality) and environmental factors (work schedule). Use of electronics should be assessed, because there is increasing evidence that screen time, such as smartphone and tablet use, before bed can alter circadian patterns and increase insomnia symptoms. A sleep diary can facilitate collection of an accurate sleep history, and obtaining a collateral history from the patient's sleep partner may shed light on specific sleep-related disorders. Use of the Insomnia Severity Index or the Athens Insomnia Scale can be helpful as part of a comprehensive sleep assessment.

Diagnostic testing, such as polysomnography, is not a first-line approach and is useful only when the clinical presentation is suggestive of a sleep disorder, such as sleep apnea, narcolepsy, or sleep movement disorder (see
MKSAP 19 Pulmonary and Critical Care Medicine

The goals of treatment are to improve overall sleep and quality of life. Effective treatment programs are multimodal in their approach and include CBT for insomnia (CBT-I); sleep hygiene techniques; environmental changes; and, in poorly controlled cases, pharmacologic therapy.

CBT-I is recommended as first-line therapy for insomnia. This multicomponent treatment includes cognitive therapy (to address maladaptive beliefs and expectations about sleep), educational interventions (such as sleep hygiene), and behavioral interventions (such as sleep restriction therapy, stimulus-control therapy, and relaxation techniques). CBT-I may be delivered in various formats, such as individual or group therapy, web-based modules, or written materials. CBT-I provides significant value over pharmacologic-driven approaches and carries little risk for adverse effects.

Brief behavioral therapy for insomnia is an abbreviated version of CBT-I, focusing on the behavioral components of sleep restriction, stimulus control, and sleep hygiene only. It is more convenient for many patients and of greater value than pharmacologic therapy.
Sleep hygiene strategies focus on optimizing environmental factors and reducing stimuli

. Blue-light–filtering glasses or software programs are frequently used by the general public, but their effectiveness has not been established. Sleep hygiene education has not been shown to be effective as a standalone therapy for chronic insomnia. Sleep restriction therapy, which entails limiting the amount of time in bed to increase sleep efficiency, also may be used.

Physicians should engage in a thorough shared decision-making process to decide whether to add pharmacologic therapy to CBT-I in patients with refractory insomnia. Several pharmacologic agents have been demonstrated to improve sleep latency and total sleep time

, but few studies have examined their overall effect on functioning and quality of life. Pharmacologic therapy is also associated with harms, including daytime drowsiness, increased risk for falls and hip fracture, and medication-related hallucinations. Factors that should be considered before initiating pharmacologic therapy for insomnia are included in
. Ideally, medications should be taken in short-term trials (no more than 4-5 weeks) and should be selected to target the most problematic phase of sleep (onset versus maintenance).

Benzodiazepines induce sedation by activating inhibitory γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors. These drugs decrease sleep latency and have a sleep-promoting effect. The associated risk for rebound insomnia, addiction potential, and sedation make benzodiazepines poor candidates for treatment of insomnia, particularly in combination with other sedating agents (including opioids) and in geriatric populations.

Nonbenzodiazepine GABA-receptor agonists are typically more selective in their activity at the GABA receptor. These agents (zolpidem, eszopiclone, and zaleplon) have a rapid onset of action and short half-life, making them better choices for patients with difficulty initiating sleep. Long-acting formulations and formulations meant for use with middle-of-the-night awakenings also are available. There is potential for prolonged impaired driving skills, somnolence, and amnesia with use of zolpidem, eszopiclone, and zaleplon, and reports of serious or fatal injuries associated with complex sleep behaviors prompted the FDA to issue a boxed warning for these agents. Few data on long-term safety or efficacy are available, and long-term therapy should be avoided. There are few choices for long-term pharmacologic treatment of chronic insomnia, although very-low-dose doxepin may be effective.

The melatonin receptor agonist ramelteon can decrease sleep latency and increase total sleep time, although the effect is modest and can be measured in minutes. Side effects are less common with ramelteon than with GABA-receptor agonists.

Patients frequently use over-the-counter medications for insomnia, including anticholinergic and antihistamine medications and melatonin. Evidence supporting over-the-counter sleep aid use is limited, and the American Academy of Sleep Medicine found insufficient evidence to recommend any over-the-counter medication because of associated anticholinergic side effects and carry-over daytime sleepiness. In addition, there is a growing body of evidence linking long-term anticholinergic use to an increased risk for dementia. Antihistamines should be avoided in older adults, in whom the risk for side effects is magnified. Over-the-counter melatonin may be effective for circadian rhythm disruptions and has a more favorable side effect profile than antihistamines, but data supporting its efficacy are poor.
Diagnostic testing, such as polysomnography, is usually unnecessary in the evaluation of insomnia unless the clinical presentation is suggestive of a sleep disorder.
First-line therapy for insomnia is cognitive behavioral therapy, which includes cognitive therapy, education on sleep hygiene, and behavioral interventions.
Pharmacologic therapies for insomnia are associated with adverse effects and should be initiated only in patients with insomnia refractory to nonpharmacologic interventions.

Lower extremity edema is a common symptom in inpatient and outpatient settings. It results from accumulation of interstitial fluid in the most dependent part of the body and may be secondary to several different pathophysiologic mechanisms. The most common causes include venous obstruction or insufficiency, heart failure (including right-sided heart failure secondary to pulmonary disease), cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome and hypoalbuminemia of other etiologies, and use of certain medications

. If lower extremity edema is unilateral, it is usually the result of a mechanical obstruction to venous or lymphatic flow, such as deep venous thrombosis or cancer. Obstruction of the lymphatic system is a less common mechanism of edema.

A detailed history and physical examination will suggest the cause of lower extremity edema in most patients. For unilateral leg edema, the clinical probability of deep venous thrombosis needs to be determined. D-dimer and/or Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities may be necessary. Cellulitis can be considered on the basis of findings. For bilateral leg edema, reasonable initial laboratory testing includes measurement of kidney and liver function, urinalysis (for detection of protein), and albumin measurement. The decision to pursue further testing (e.g., echocardiography) should be guided by the findings on the initial evaluation.

Chronic venous insufficiency is a common condition in which the veins or valves in the lower extremities are incompetent, resulting in pooling of blood in the legs. The most common cause is venous hypertension, which is usually induced by acquired risk factors but can be congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome). Symptoms include aching, itching, restlessness, heaviness, swelling, and pain in the legs.

A thorough history and physical examination should be performed. The examination may reveal edema, dilated veins (both varicosities and superficial telangiectasias), thin or hyperpigmented skin, and ulceration. Physical findings are best observed in the gravity-dependent upright position. Chronic venous insufficiency is a clinical diagnosis, but venous duplex Doppler ultrasonography can be used if the diagnosis is in doubt and in those considering intervention.

Conservative measures, including exercise, leg elevation, lifestyle changes (weight loss), and compression therapy (20-50 mm Hg depending on the stage of disease), are first-line treatments. Exercise has not been shown to improve leg edema but can contribute to other outcomes, such as weight loss. The presence of skin changes or ulceration should prompt at least 30 mm Hg of compression (see

). Skin care is another important part of management, and daily use of topical moisturizers may reduce skin breakdown and prevent infection. Stasis dermatitis may require sparing use of a topical steroid. Wound care, including use of hydrocolloids and foam dressings, is essential to control drainage from ulcers and to prevent maceration of the surrounding skin. Many drugs, including horse chestnut extracts and other nonprescription agents, have been studied for chronic venous insufficiency without ulceration; however, no medications are FDA approved for this condition, and only low-quality studies of their use have been published. Patients with bothersome spider veins and small varicose veins can undergo sclerotherapy, thermocoagulation, or laser therapy. Patients with confirmed reflux and persistent symptoms despite conservative therapy may be treated with venous ablation; stripping; excision; or, in the case of stenosis and obstruction, stenting. Surgical options can be considered for those with symptoms that are refractory to medical and endovenous therapies.
Venous stasis ulcers, arterial insufficiency ulcers, and neuropathic ulcers are the most common ulcerations of the feet and lower extremities
. The proper diagnosis is important because treatments are directed at the underlying cause. Arterial insufficiency ulcers are discussed in
, and neuropathic ulcers are discussed in

Venous stasis ulcers account for up to 70% of all leg ulcers. They occur on the lower extremities in the area from the mid-calf to the ankle, most commonly near the medial malleolus, and are associated with signs of chronic venous insufficiency. Venous stasis ulcers can be single or multiple and are typically irregularly shaped, shallow, and often weep serous fluid
. The presence of fibrinous tissue is common, and ulcers are rarely necrotic. Pain may or may not be present.

Physical findings suggestive of a venous stasis ulcer include concomitant edema, varicosities, eczematous changes, brown pigmentation from hemosiderin deposition, lipodermatosclerosis (fibrosis of subcutaneous tissue), atrophie blanche (pale plaques of scar tissue), and evidence of healed ulcers. Like chronic venous insufficiency, diagnosis is usually made clinically, although duplex ultrasonography can be helpful in evaluating venous reflux and obstruction, or if the diagnosis is unclear. The ankle-brachial index should be measured to rule out concurrent arterial disease.

Treatment consists of compression therapy (≥30 mm Hg), which improves venous flow, reduces edema, and promotes fibrinolysis. Compression therapy is best administered by using high-compression, multicomponent bandaging; other options include elastic or inelastic compression bandages (Unna boots, compression stockings) or intermittent pneumonic compression devices. An absolute contraindication to compression therapy is an ankle-brachial index of 0.5 or less, although cautious use is advised for any patient with an ankle-brachial index less than 0.9. For patients who cannot be treated with compression therapy, referral to a vascular specialist should be considered.

Local wound care includes debridement of devitalized tissue. Simple nonadherent dressings appear to be as effective as other more expensive dressings, and the addition of topical cadexomer iodine may improve healing. When added to standard care, pentoxifylline, simvastatin, and aspirin have each individually been shown to increase ulcer healing, although the relative effectiveness of combination therapy is unknown. Antibiotics should be reserved for patients with signs of infection, including erythema and tenderness at the site of the ulcer, lymphangitis, rapidly increasing ulcer size, and fever.
The most common causes of lower extremity edema include venous obstruction or insufficiency, heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome, and medication use.
Conservative measures, including exercise, leg elevation, lifestyle changes, and compression stockings, are first-line therapies for chronic venous insufficiency.
The mainstay of venous ulcer treatment is compression therapy, which improves venous flow, reduces edema, and promotes fibrinolysis.
Routine use of systemic antibiotics is not recommended for the treatment of venous stasis ulcers, except for patients with suspected infection.

Medically unexplained symptoms (MUS) are symptoms that cannot be attributed to a specific medical cause after a thorough medical evaluation. The prevalence of patients with at least one unexplained symptom ranges from 40% to 49%. Patients with MUS are frequently seen in both primary and subspecialty clinics, resulting in significantly increased health care utilization. The costs associated with MUS are estimated at more than $250 billion annually.
Central sensitization has a potential role in the formation of MUS as well as in some common chronic pain syndromes, such as fibromyalgia and irritable bowel syndrome

. Central sensitization occurs when central nervous system hyperexcitability and reduced inhibitory responses lead to pain, often in the absence of nociceptive stimuli; sensory disturbances, such as allodynia and hyperalgesia; and alterations in autonomic, motor, and cognitive function. It is often precipitated by a prodromal event, such as infection, physical or emotional trauma, surgery, medical illness, or prolonged stress. Although patients with central sensitization demonstrate changes to the peripheral immune system, hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, and nerve fiber density, these changes are consequences of the disease process rather than primary pathophysiologic mechanisms. The National Institutes of Health has coined the term chronic overlapping pain conditions to describe the interrelatedness of many of these conditions, including those listed in

Common symptoms in patients with MUS include fatigue, headache, abdominal pain, musculoskeletal pain (back pain, myalgia, arthralgia), dizziness, paresthesia, generalized weakness, transient edema, insomnia, dyspnea, chest pain, chronic facial pain, chronic pelvic pain, and chemical sensitivities. MUS appear more frequently in women, persons with lower levels of education, and those with lower socioeconomic status.

There is no formal approach to the diagnostic evaluation of MUS; however, the initial evaluation should involve a thorough history and physical examination related to each symptom. Clinicians must address symptoms in a focused manner and diligently review any previous diagnostic evaluations. Laboratory and radiographic studies should be guided by the findings on the history and physical examination, and subspecialty referrals should be used judiciously. Given the high comorbidity of mood disturbances in patients with MUS, patients with features concerning for an underlying mood disorder should be evaluated accordingly.
Patients with MUS must be distinguished from those with somatic symptom disorders, which are psychiatric conditions with specific diagnostic criteria (see
). Although many somatic symptom disorders involve MUS, most patients with MUS do not meet the diagnostic criteria for these disorders.

If an underlying medical cause cannot be identified after an appropriately thorough evaluation, it is imperative that clinicians have an open and honest discussion with the patient, being mindful to acknowledge the patient's concerns and frustrations. Frequently, patients will request, or even demand, additional testing and consultations that may not be clinically indicated. Although doing so may be challenging, clinicians should limit additional evaluations to those deemed medically necessary because unrevealing studies provide negligible reassurance, pose iatrogenic risks, and increase patient anxiety.

The foundation of MUS management is an effective therapeutic relationship. Patients should be treated respectfully and cared for in a nonjudgmental manner. It is important not only to expect but also to accept the patient's feelings of frustration; acknowledging these feelings early in the patient's management course can help to build and strengthen the therapeutic alliance. Patients often fear that they will be perceived as producing factitious symptoms or malingering, and it is crucial to address these concerns directly if raised.

Management of MUS requires a patient-focused, holistic, and multimodal approach. The goals of management are restoration of function, decreased symptom focus, and acquisition of coping mechanisms rather than abatement of symptoms. It should be made clear to patients that the treatment of MUS will probably not be curative and that symptoms may persist. Patients should be encouraged to develop short-term and long-term goals with the recognition that many goals will change from a physical symptom focus to a psychosocial focus. If additional symptoms arise, clinicians should respond empathically and perform an appropriately thorough investigation.

Interventions that may benefit patients with MUS include CBT, physical therapy, occupational therapy, individual or group psychotherapy, social support, biofeedback therapy, graded exercise therapy, stress management activities, and training in coping mechanisms. Patients with comorbid mood disorders should be considered for a trial of antidepressant therapy and referral to a psychiatrist or psychologist. Given the wide-ranging effects of MUS, treatment should be focused on both physical and psychosocial aspects
Central sensitization plays a role in many medically unexplained symptoms as well as in some common chronic pain syndromes, such as fibromyalgia and irritable bowel syndrome.

In patients with medically unexplained symptoms, clinicians should limit diagnostic testing to those tests deemed medically necessary because unrevealing studies provide negligible reassurance, pose iatrogenic risks, and result in additional patient anxiety.
The goals of management in patients with medically unexplained symptoms are restoration of function, decreased symptom focus, and acquisition of coping mechanisms rather than abatement of symptoms.

Syncope is complete, transient loss of consciousness and postural tone due to global cerebral hypoperfusion resulting from a decrease in cardiac output or systemic vascular resistance. The onset of syncope is sudden and abrupt, and recovery is rapid, with a complete return to the baseline level of functioning. Syncope has a reported cumulative incidence of 3% to 6% over a 10-year period and accounts for 1% to 2% of all emergency department visits. Approximately 40% of adults have experienced a syncopal event, and 80% of these patients had a first episode before age 30 years. Although the Framingham Heart Study found that 44% of patients who experienced a syncopal event did not seek medical care, a 2014 financial analysis showed that the diagnostic and therapeutic costs associated with syncope exceed $4.1 billion annually in the United States.

Syncope can be classified according to the specific etiology of the event as neurally mediated (reflex), cardiovascular, orthostatic, neurologic, psychogenic, or idiopathic. These etiologies can be further subdivided according to the specific pathophysiologic mechanism. Approximately 40% of syncopal events are unexplained (idiopathic).

Neurally mediated syncope, or reflex syncope, is the most common form and is seen primarily in younger adults. The underlying syncopal mechanism, termed the neurocardiogenic or vasodepressor reflex, is a response of vasodilation, bradycardia, and systemic hypotension, which leads to transient hypoperfusion of the brain. Neurally mediated syncope includes vasovagal syncope, which is provoked by noxious stimuli, fear, stress, or heat overexposure; situational syncope, which is triggered by cough, micturition, defecation, or deglutition; and carotid sinus hypersensitivity, which is sometimes experienced during head rotation, shaving, or use of a tight-fitting neck collar. Prodromal symptoms, including nausea and diaphoresis, are classically present before the syncopal event, and fatigue and generalized weakness are typically present afterward.

Cardiovascular syncope is the second most common form of syncope and is associated with increased morbidity, mortality (including sudden death), and direct traumatic injury. Historical characteristics that are associated with increased probability of cardiac versus noncardiac causes are listed in

. Cardiovascular syncopal events often occur suddenly and usually without a significant prodrome, although chest pain and palpitations may be present briefly. Causes of cardiovascular syncope include arrhythmia; coronary artery disease; and structural and obstructive disease, including aortic and pulmonary valve stenosis, obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic dissection, and cardiac tamponade. Pulmonary embolism is increasingly appreciated as a cause of syncope, with a prevalence as high as 17% in some studies.

Orthostatic syncope is the third most common form of syncope and predominantly affects older adults. It classically occurs after changes in position and is typically associated with prodromal symptoms, such as lightheadedness. Orthostatic syncope is most commonly caused by hypovolemia, medications, or alcohol intoxication. Less commonly, primary autonomic failure (Parkinson disease, multiple system atrophy, multiple sclerosis) or secondary autonomic failure (diabetes, amyloidosis, connective tissue disease, spinal cord injury) can lead to neurogenic orthostatic syncope.

Neurologic conditions are a rare cause of syncope. Cerebrovascular events (transient ischemic attack, ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke), seizures, and direct head trauma may lead to transient loss of consciousness but should be distinguished from true syncope. Cerebrovascular events that lead to true syncope primarily involve the posterior (vertebrobasilar) circulation and usually present with concomitant symptoms of dizziness, vertigo, gait changes, and focal neurologic findings. Anterior circulation involvement rarely leads to syncope. Seizures can be confused with syncopal events, and bystander information can help distinguish between the two. A prospective study demonstrated that the features most suggestive of a seizure in patients with loss of consciousness were witnessed abnormal posturing, involuntary head turning, and tongue laceration. Auras, incontinence, and prolonged postepisode confusion also favor a seizure.
Psychogenic syncope, which has been referred to as pseudosyncope, generally occurs in younger patients with underlying anxiety, panic disorder, or depression.

The American Heart Association (AHA), American College of Cardiology (ACC), and Heart Rhythm Society (HRS) jointly conclude that the history and physical examination are the most important diagnostic tools in determining the underlying cause of a syncopal event. The history should focus on eliciting information on prodromal or postepisode symptoms, comorbid medical or psychiatric conditions, the psychosocial context of the event, and bystander information. A thorough review of the patient's prescription and over-the-counter medications should be completed.

The physical examination should include an in-depth cardiovascular evaluation, including orthostatic (postural) blood pressure measurements, as well as a basic neurologic examination to evaluate for focal defects. Carotid hypersensitivity can be assessed by using carotid sinus massage in individuals older than 40 years with syncope of unknown cause; however, this technique is contraindicated in patients with known carotid disease or transient ischemic attack/stroke within the past 3 months.

The AHA/ACC/HRS syncope guideline recommends that an ECG be obtained in all patients with syncope to identify underlying arrhythmia, myocardial ischemia, or QT prolongation. In general, additional studies have a low diagnostic yield; however, when there is a moderate to high pretest probability of a specific condition, these studies can help to identify or confirm a diagnosis

. Echocardiography is indicated to detect suspected valvular heart disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and reduced left ventricular function. An exercise stress test is most likely to be helpful in patients with exercise-related syncope. ECG monitoring (in the emergency department with an ambulatory monitor, event monitor, or implantable loop recorder) should be considered in selected patients with a probable arrhythmic cause; the choice of test is based on the frequency and nature of the syncopal event (see

). Targeted laboratory studies are guided by findings in the history and physical examination. Tilt-table testing is most commonly useful in patients suspected of having recurrent vasovagal syncope or when the initial evaluation of delayed orthostatic hypotension is not diagnostic. Cardiac imaging with CT or MRI is most useful when structural or infiltrative heart disease is suspected but initial diagnostic tests are inconclusive. CT angiography is indicated for patients with a significant pretest probability of pulmonary embolism. Electrophysiology studies are reserved for patients suspected of having an arrhythmic cause of syncope, and the decision to perform electroencephalography should be based on the specific clinical scenario. The American College of Physicians recommends against routinely obtaining brain imaging (CT or MRI) in cases of syncope that do not involve objective focal neurologic findings. Carotid duplex ultrasonography plays no role in the evaluation of syncope.

title.__html: Risk Stratification and Decision for Hospital Admission

children: Risk Stratification and Decision for Hospital Admission

The AHA/ACC/HRS syncope guideline recommends evaluation to determine the cause of syncope and assessment of the patient's short- and long-term morbidity and mortality risk. Short-term adverse events and deaths are primarily determined by the underlying etiology and the effectiveness of the treatment. Risk scores have been developed to assist in risk stratification and to guide patient disposition; however, they generally do not outperform unstructured clinical judgment. The presence of high-risk clinical characteristics should prompt consideration of hospitalization
. Patients with likely reflex-mediated syncope who do not have serious underlying medical conditions can be managed in the outpatient setting.

Neurally mediated syncope can be managed with reassurance and education on avoiding provoking measures. Physical counterpressure techniques, such as leg crossing, squatting, or handgrip maneuvers, can be beneficial for neurally mediated syncope with a prolonged prodrome. Cardiovascular syncope management should target the specific underlying cardiac condition. Orthostatic syncope may be treated with volume expansion (with salt liberalization, if appropriate), reconsideration of contributing medications, compression stockings, and education on postural changes. Initiation of additional vasoactive agents, such as fludrocortisone or midodrine, can be considered; however, available evidence on their efficacy is limited and conflicting. Referral to a mental health specialist is appropriate for patients with psychogenic syncope.

The underlying cause of the syncopal event determines the prognosis. Patients with a syncopal episode are at increased risk for all-cause mortality (hazard ratio [HR], 1.3; 95% CI, 1.1-1.5) and cardiovascular events (HR, 1.3; 95% CI, 1.0-1.6). The risk for death is even greater in cases of cardiac syncope (HR, 2.0; 95% CI, 1.5-2.7). Neurally mediated and orthostatic syncope do not portend increased cardiovascular mortality.

Syncope of any cause, especially if recurrent, can severely affect quality of life, functional independence, and self-confidence. Clinicians should assess for any ensuing mood changes, the need for skilled assistance, and the need for possible driving restrictions (which vary per state law).
The history and physical examination, including orthostatic (postural) blood pressure measurement, are the most important diagnostic tools in determining the underlying cause of syncope.

An ECG should be obtained in all patients with syncope to identify underlying arrhythmia, ischemia, or QT prolongation; other tests have low diagnostic yield and should be performed only when there is a moderate to high pretest probability of a specific underlying condition.
The American College of Physicians recommends against routinely performing brain imaging in cases of syncope that do not involve objective focal neurologic findings.
Neurally mediated syncope is treated with reassurance and avoidance of provoking measures; physical counterpressure techniques can be useful in patients with a prolonged prodrome.

Orthostatic syncope may be treated with volume expansion (with salt liberalization, if appropriate), reconsideration of contributing medications, compression stockings, and education on postural changes.

In-flight medical emergencies are relatively common during air travel, occurring in an estimated 1 in 600 flights. The most common in-flight emergencies are presyncope or syncope (typically vasovagal), which account for up to one third of in-flight emergencies. The frequency of these events is explained by the physiologic conditions in flight, including low humidity and high altitudes. Other common in-flight emergencies include gastrointestinal disorders (diarrhea and vomiting), cardiovascular symptoms (chest pain), and respiratory symptoms (dyspnea and hyperventilation). Most aircraft cabins are pressurized to 6000 to 8000 feet, and the lower partial pressure of oxygen may cause dyspnea in those with significant underlying cardiopulmonary disease. In-flight cardiac arrest is rare (approximately 0.2% of in-flight emergencies); however, it is responsible for the majority of in-flight deaths. In the event of suspected acute myocardial infarction or stroke, immediate flight diversion should be recommended to the crew. Other frequently encountered issues include trauma caused by objects falling from overhead bins, hypoglycemia, psychiatric problems (most commonly anxiety or phobias), allergic reactions, seizures, headaches, and obstetric or gynecologic events.

Physicians who respond to in-flight emergencies have access to medical resources and support. Airlines based in the United States are mandated by the Federal Aviation Administration to carry at least one automated external defibrillator; supplemental oxygen; and a medical kit that contains a stethoscope, sphygmomanometer, gloves, airway supplies, intravenous access supplies (needles, syringes, saline), and some basic medications (epinephrine, lidocaine, atropine, aspirin, nitroglycerin, antihistamines, bronchodilators, and dextrose). Many U.S. airlines augment their kits with additional supplies. The contents of international kits may vary. In addition, patients experiencing an in-flight emergency may have their own prescription medications with them.

The physician's role in in-flight medical emergencies involves assessing the patient, establishing a diagnosis when possible, administering basic medical treatments, providing reassurance as appropriate, and recommending flight diversion if necessary. Most airlines contract with 24-hour call centers staffed with emergency medicine physicians with special training on the in-flight environment. Such support is accessed through the pilot, and direct communication between the physician providing assistance and the ground-based support physician may not be possible. Flight crews are required to receive cardiopulmonary resuscitation training, including training on the use of automated external defibrillators, and to be familiar with first-aid equipment. If the patient's condition is critical, the physician can recommend diversion of the flight to the nearest airport, although the ultimate decision rests with the aircraft captain.

In the United States, physicians are not legally mandated to assist in the event of an in-flight emergency, although some countries do impose such obligations. The laws of the country in which the aircraft is registered usually prevail. Ethically, physicians should provide assistance as able. The Aviation Medical Assistance Act of 1998 includes a Good Samaritan provision that protects individuals who are medically qualified “from liability for rendering assistance unless that person is engaged in gross negligence or willful misconduct,” such as providing care while intoxicated. Providers should practice within their scope of training, be mindful of patient privacy, and document the patient encounter.

The physician's role in in-flight emergencies involves assessing the patient, establishing a diagnosis when possible, administering basic medical treatments, providing reassurance as appropriate, and recommending flight diversion if necessary.
In the United States, physicians are not legally mandated to assist in the event of an in-flight emergency; however, physicians have an ethical obligation to provide assistance as able.

Food allergy is an adverse reaction resulting from an abnormal immune response that reproducibly occurs after exposure to a food. Food allergy may be IgE mediated, non–IgE mediated, or mixed. Common food allergens include peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, milk, eggs, soy, and wheat.

Symptoms may include flushing, pruritus, urticaria, wheezing, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and light-headedness. Food allergy may result in several clinical syndromes, including anaphylaxis, eosinophilic esophagitis, oral allergy syndrome, urticaria, angioedema, and atopic dermatitis. Food allergy and asthma commonly coexist.

Diagnosis may be difficult and is often confused with food intolerance. Food allergy should be suspected in patients who present with anaphylaxis or other allergic symptoms that develop within minutes to hours of food ingestion. A detailed history to identify causative foods is critical in focusing the evaluation. Skin prick testing and allergen-specific serum IgE levels can help identify causative foods, but neither is diagnostic. Intradermal testing and total serum IgE level measurements are not recommended because sufficient evidence is lacking. Food elimination diets and/or oral food challenges under the supervision of an allergist may be needed for more definitive diagnosis in some cases.

There is no specific treatment for food allergy; prevention by avoidance of food allergens is first-line management, and antihistamines are recommended in managing symptoms when they arise. Cases of anaphylaxis should be treated emergently with epinephrine, bronchodilators, antihistamines, corticosteroids, and supplemental oxygen.
Food allergies are diagnosed through a detailed history and physical examination; skin prick testing; specific serum IgE levels; and, in some cases, a food elimination trial and/or food challenge.
Avoidance of food allergens is the mainstay of treatment.

Recurrent, transient, positional; usually provoked by turning over or getting in and out of bed

Spontaneous, usually sustained; may be worsened by positional change

title.__html: HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew) Examination and Interpretation

children: HINTS (Head Impulse, Nystagmus, and Test of Skew) Examination and Interpretation

With the patient focusing on the examiner, the examiner slowly moves the patient's head in either direction about 20 degrees and then rapidly rotates back to midline, while assessing for catch-up saccades
Presence of catch-up saccades (consistent with peripheral cause of vertigo)
Absence of catch-up saccades (consistent with central cause of vertigo)
Examiner observes for the presence and directionality of nystagmus on lateral gaze
Examiner alternates covering and uncovering each of the patient's eyes and assesses for vertical adjustment or refixation

footnotes: All present is suggestive of vestibular neuronitis.
Any present in the correct clinical scenario is concerning for stroke.
Vertical deviation of one eye compared with the other.
Time to onset of nystagmus after positioning the patient.
Decrease in the intensity and duration of nystagmus with repeated maneuvers.

title.__html: Causes of Dyspnea Based on Symptom Onset and Progression

children: Causes of Dyspnea Based on Symptom Onset and Progression
Ensure adequate exposure to natural light
Avoid the following close to bedtime:
Substances that may fragment sleep (caffeine, nicotine, alcohol, pseudoephedrine)
Establish a regular relaxing bedtime routine (30 minutes)
Associate the bed and the bedroom with sleep
Keep the bedroom quiet and dark
Keep stable bedtime and arising time
Spend no more than 20 minutes awake in bed
Spend no more than 8 hours in bed
Avoid screen time (use of television, computer/tablet, or phone)

footnotes: Information from Masters PA. In the clinic. Insomnia.

title.__html: FDA-Approved Prescription Drug Treatment for Insomnia

children: FDA-Approved Prescription Drug Treatment for Insomnia
The recommended initial dosage was reduced to 1 mg because of prolonged impaired driving skills, memory, and coordination at the previously recommended 3-mg dosage
5-mg dose recommended for debilitated or low-body-weight patients
Doses ≥10 mg are not recommended for women owing to prolonged sedation
Indicated for as-needed use for treatment of middle-of-the-night insomnia with ≥4 h of sleep time remaining
Best choice for chronic pharmacologic therapy, if necessary
Insufficient Evidence to Recommend for or Against
Next-day driving impairment possible after 10-mg dose
The recommended initial dosage is 10 mg; the daily dosage should not exceed 20 mg
Short-acting benzodiazepines have been associated with an increased risk for anterograde amnesia

footnotes: All agents are classified as schedule IV by the Drug Enforcement Agency except doxepin and ramelteon, which are not scheduled.
Onset of action: rapid = 15-30 minutes; slow = 30-60 minutes.
Based on elimination half-life and preparation: short = 1-5 hours; intermediate = 5-12 hours; long = >12 hours.

Recommendations from Mysliwiec V, Martin JL, Ulmer CS, et al. The management of chronic insomnia disorder and obstructive sleep apnea: synopsis of the 2019 U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and U.S. Department of Defense clinical practice guidelines.
Adapted with permission from Masters PA. In the clinic. Insomnia.
