title.__html: Factors to Consider When Prescribing Drugs to Treat Insomnia

children: Factors to Consider When Prescribing Drugs to Treat Insomnia
Avoid long–half-life medications, including long–half-life metabolites
Be aware of potential interactions between drugs, including over-the-counter drugs
Caution patients who are receiving these medications about interaction with alcohol
Review potential side effects: daytime sleepiness, complex sleep behaviors, serious injury, or death
Confer with the patient to determine an appropriate period of use
Use a γ-aminobutyric acid agonist before other sedative-hypnotics for treatment of acute or short-term insomnia
Look for rebound insomnia after discontinuation
Consider consulting a sleep specialist before starting long-term therapy with hypnotic medication
Consider intermittent or long-term use of hypnotic medications, depending on the clinical situation

footnotes: Adapted with permission from Masters PA. In the clinic. Insomnia.
. © 2014, American College of Physicians.

title.__html: Differential Diagnosis of Lower Extremity Edema

children: Differential Diagnosis of Lower Extremity Edema
Gradual-onset leg aching/heaviness that is more likely to improve with elevation/recumbency and walking (decreased venous pressure)
Edema (most commonly bilateral but can be unilateral) that usually spares forefoot
Hyperpigmentation (hemosiderin deposits); telangiectasias, reticular veins, varicose veins; eczematous dermatitis and lipodermatosclerosis leading to ulceration, especially over the medial malleolus
Dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, elevated jugular venous pressure, lung crackles, ventricular gallop, symmetric pitting edema
Urinalysis, random urine albumin-creatinine ratio, serum creatinine level
Symmetric pitting edema, ascites, spider angiomas, palmar erythema, jaundice/icterus
Liver chemistry tests, albumin level, INR
Symptoms of hypothyroidism, nonpitting bilateral edema
Thyroid-stimulating hormone level, serum thyroxine level
Brawny induration; pitting edema present initially; nonpitting present late in process; involves feet (square toes)
Kaposi-Stemmer sign (inability to pinch a fold of skin on the dorsal surface of the base of the second toe)
Can consider CT of the abdomen/pelvis, lymphoscintigraphy
Fatty tissue accumulation, nonpitting edema that spares the feet
Daytime sleepiness, snoring, witnessed apnea, neck circumference >43 cm (17 in), symmetric pitting edema
Exertional dyspnea, elevated jugular venous pressure, prominent jugular venous
Unilateral, painful edema (most commonly) that may be tender on examination; typically pitting edema
Should be strongly suspected with acute edema <72 h
D-dimer and/or lower extremity ultrasonography depending on pretest probability
Drugs (vasodilators, NSAIDs, gabapentinoids, hormones, antiestrogens, thiazolidinediones, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers)
Gradual-onset, bilateral pitting edema that usually improves with recumbency; one side may be larger than the other, particularly if there is more pronounced venous disease
No diagnostic testing; symptoms resolve within days of discontinuing the offending agent

title.__html: Common Types of Foot and Leg Ulcers

children: Common Types of Foot and Leg Ulcers
Mid-calf to ankle, often over medial malleolus
Pain variably present; irregularly shaped, shallow, weeping serous fluid; normal arterial pulses
Edema, venous varicosities, eczematous changes, hyperpigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis
Painful; sharply demarcated borders; dry, pale gray or yellow wound base
Evidence of atherosclerosis, poor pulses, hair loss, shiny skin
Advanced age, smoking, obesity, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, hypertension
Decreased sensation, callus formation, neuropathic (Charcot) arthropathy
Systemic exertional intolerance disease (formerly chronic fatigue syndrome/myalgic encephalomyelitis)

title.__html: Follow-up Management of the Patient with Medically Unexplained Symptoms

children: Follow-up Management of the Patient with Medically Unexplained Symptoms
Maintaining an effective relationship with the patient
Elicit and address the patient's emotional concerns; use a negotiated rather than a prescriptive approach; tailor care to patient's personality; address your own negative reactions to the patient

Monitor the provider-patient relationship regularly as you would, for example, monitor blood pressure in a patient with hypertension. Ask, “So, how is this going? How are you and I working together?” Examples of indicators of an effective relationship are adherence to the treatment plan, friendliness, improved eye contact, positive statements about the provider and the treatment
Schedule regular, consistent, time-contingent visits rather than ad hoc (as-needed) visits; give all medications on a scheduled rather than on an as-needed basis
Titrate number of scheduled visits and amount of treatment to patient's needs and progress
Consider the lowest effective dosage of antidepressant and nonopioid analgesics
Minimize or avoid use of opioids and tranquilizers
Review patient's diary and facilitate understanding of how his or her thoughts, emotions, and behaviors are related to symptoms
Educate the patient so that the patient understands the plan of care and its purpose

Give appropriate praise for commitment behavior, such as completing homework; address noncommittal behavior, such as not keeping appointments or visiting an acute care facility without prior discussion
Reinforce previous short-term goals or negotiate new ones to operationalize patient's long-term goals
Help patient to identify solutions to roadblocks
Negotiate plans to adjust physical activity; recommend relaxation techniques; refer for physical therapy
Continuously encourage the patient to add new healthy behaviors and to progress in what he or she is already doing

footnotes: Adapted from Dwamena FC, Fortin AH, Smith RC. Medically unexplained symptoms. In ACP Smart Medicine (online database). Philadelphia: American College of Physicians; 2015. Accessed June 25, 2015.

title.__html: Historical Characteristics Associated with Increased Probability of Cardiac and Noncardiac Causes of Syncope

children: Historical Characteristics Associated with Increased Probability of Cardiac and Noncardiac Causes of Syncope
More Often Associated with Cardiac Causes of Syncope
Presence of known ischemic heart disease, structural heart disease, previous arrhythmias, or reduced ventricular function
Brief prodrome, such as palpitations, or sudden loss of consciousness without prodrome
Low number of syncope episodes (one or two)
Family history of inheritable conditions or premature sudden cardiac death (<50 y of age)
Presence of known congenital heart disease
More Often Associated with Noncardiac Causes of Syncope
Syncope only in the standing position
Positional change from supine or sitting to standing
Presence of prodrome: nausea, vomiting, feeling of warmth
Presence of specific triggers: dehydration, pain, distressful stimulus, medical environment
Situational triggers: cough, laugh, micturition, defecation, deglutition
Frequent recurrence and prolonged history of syncope with similar characteristics

footnotes: Reproduced with permission from Shen WK, Sheldon RS, Benditt DG, et al. 2017 ACC/AHA/HRS guideline for the evaluation and management of patients with syncope: executive summary: a report of the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association Task Force on Clinical Practice Guidelines and the Heart Rhythm Society. Circulation. 2017;136:e32.

title.__html: High-Risk Clinical Characteristics in the Patient with Syncope<sup>a</sup>

children: High-Risk Clinical Characteristics in the Patient with Syncope
Symptoms of chest discomfort or palpitations before syncope
History of structural heart abnormalities, ischemic heart disease, known arrhythmia, or heart failure
New or previously unknown left bundle branch block, bifascicular block, Brugada pattern, findings consistent with acute ischemia, nonsinus rhythm, prolonged QTc (>450 ms)
Systolic blood pressure <90 mm Hg or >180 mm Hg

footnotes: QTc = corrected QT interval.
A patient is considered at high cardiac risk if any of the above risk factors are present.

Information from Costantino G, Sun BC, Barbic F, et al. Syncope clinical management in the emergency department: a consensus from the first international workshop on syncope risk stratification in the emergency department. Eur Heart J. 2016;37:1493-8.
doi:10.1093/eurheartj/ehv378
